2026-02-06.content:
You can provide [custom metadata](https://docs.cloud.google.com/compute/docs/metadata/overview) for a
workstation's host VM.

Use the `--instance-metadata` flag with the
[`gcloud workstations configs create`](https://docs.cloud.google.com/sdk/gcloud/reference/workstations/configs/create)
and [`gcloud workstations configs update`](https://docs.cloud.google.com/sdk/gcloud/reference/workstations/configs/update)
commands. Format the metadata as a comma-separated list of key-value pairsâ€”for
example, `--instance-metadata=key1=value1,key2=value2`.

Note that updating metadata replaces all existing custom metadata for the
workstation instance.

summary.title: Add custom metadata to workstation VMs
summary.summary: You can now provide custom metadata for your workstation's host VMs. Use the --instance-metadata flag with the gcloud workstations configs create and update commands to set key-value pairs. Note that updating metadata will replace all existing custom metadata.

2026-02-06.content:
Cloud Workstations supports specifying a custom startup script to be executed on
the workstation's host VM during boot.

Provide the custom startup script as a Google Cloud Storage URL, such as
`gs://BUCKET/FILE`, using the `--startup-script-uri` flag with the
[`gcloud workstations configs create`](https://docs.cloud.google.com/sdk/gcloud/reference/workstations/configs/create) and [`gcloud workstations configs update`](https://docs.cloud.google.com/sdk/gcloud/reference/workstations/configs/update)
commands.

summary.title: Custom startup scripts for Cloud Workstations
summary.summary: You can now specify a custom startup script to run when your Cloud Workstation's host VM boots. Provide the script as a Google Cloud Storage URL using the --startup-script-uri flag with gcloud workstations configs create and update commands.

2026-01-31.content:
Cloud Workstations supports [Hyperdisk Balanced High Availability](https://docs.cloud.google.com/compute/docs/disks/hyperdisks) (`hyperdisk-balanced-ha`) for persistent directories on configurations using A3, C3, C4, G4, M3, N4, N4D, and Z3 machine series. You can specify the disk type using the `--disk-type` flag with the [`gcloud workstations configs create`](https://docs.cloud.google.com/sdk/gcloud/reference/workstations/configs/create) and [`gcloud workstations configs update`](https://docs.cloud.google.com/sdk/gcloud/reference/workstations/configs/update) commands.

Cloud Workstations supports A3 machine types with Hyperdisk only. For more details, see [Available machine types](https://docs.cloud.google.com/workstations/docs/available-machine-types) and [Available GPUs](https://docs.cloud.google.com/workstations/docs/available-gpus).

summary.title: Cloud Workstations adds Hyperdisk Balanced HA support
summary.summary: Cloud Workstations now supports Hyperdisk Balanced High Availability for persistent directories on select machine types, including A3, C3, C4, G4, M3, N4, N4D, and Z3. This enhancement improves data durability and availability for your development environments. You can configure this new disk type using the `--disk-type` flag in gcloud commands.

2025-12-05.content:
Cloud Workstations predefined images include
[Node.js](https://nodejs.org/) 24 (LTS). The previous version, 20.19.6, is no
longer pre-installed. To continue using a previous version, you can
[customize your container images](https://docs.cloud.google.com/workstations/docs/customize-container-images)
to include it or add a version manager like [NVM](https://www.nvmnode.com/).

summary.title: Node.js 24 now available in Cloud Workstations
summary.summary: Cloud Workstations now includes Node.js 24 (LTS) as a predefined image, replacing version 20.19.6. If you need to use a previous version, you can customize your container images or use a version manager like NVM.

2025-12-05.content:
Cloud Workstations predefined images include
[Eclipse Temurin](https://adoptium.net/temurin) JDK 21 and 25. JDK 11 is no longer
pre-installed. To continue using JDK 11,
[customize your container images](https://docs.cloud.google.com/workstations/docs/customize-container-images).

summary.title: Cloud Workstations Image Update
summary.summary: Cloud Workstations now includes Temurin JDK 21 and 25. JDK 11 is no longer pre-installed. To keep using JDK 11, customize your container images.

2025-07-07.content: Cloud Workstations is available in the `europe-central2` region (Warsaw). For more information, see [Locations](https://cloud.google.com/workstations/docs/locations).

summary.title: Cloud Workstations now in Warsaw
summary.summary: Cloud Workstations is now accessible in the `europe-central2` region, located in Warsaw. For a comprehensive list of available regions, please refer to the documentation.

2025-06-09.content: The JetBrains [readiness server](https://cloud.google.com/workstations/docs/develop-code-using-local-jetbrains-ides#add_a_server_readiness_check) lets you configure the port it listens on and the timeout when you specify the `JETBRAINS_READY_SERVER_PORT` and `JETBRAINS_READY_SERVER_TIMEOUT` environment variables in your workstation environment. For more information about setting environment variables, see [Customizing your environment](https://cloud.google.com/workstations/docs/create-configuration#customize_environment).

summary.title: JetBrains Readiness Server Configuration
summary.summary: You can now configure the JetBrains readiness server port and timeout using environment variables. This allows for greater flexibility in customizing your development environment.
